column1: Macron Tells Biden That Cooperation With U.S. Cannot Be Dependence

column1: Fact-Checking Biden’s First Week in Office
column2: All but three of 20 claims the president made were accurate, demonstrating his regard for basic facts and his proclivity to err when speaking off the cuff.

column1: A California University Tries to Shield an Entire City From Coronavirus
column2: The University of California, Davis, is providing free testing, masks and quarantine housing to tens of thousands of people who live nearby.

column1: Federal Court Lifts Block on Trump Policy Expelling Migrant Children at the Border
column2: The prospect of border agents again turning away children is likely to renew pressure on the Biden administration.

column1: E.U. Pushes for AstraZeneca to Provide More Vaccines
column2: The European Union is pushing for AstraZeneca to supply more doses of its Covid-19 vaccine after announcing on Wednesday that it would cut deliveries by 60 percent due to manufacturing issues.

column1: What’s Happening to Our Economy Is Like a Natural Disaster
column2: Ezra Klein and Paul Krugman discuss Covid economics, cryptocurrencies and deficit delusions.

column1: The Impact of Teacher Deaths
column2: They have shaken communities and upended the school reopening debate.
column3: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick

column1: Amazon’s Cynical, Anti-Union Attack on Mail Voting

column1: The Senate Needs Absentee Voting, Too

column2: Our grandson’s friends don’t socialize safely, so we don’t want him to see them. How do we keep his anger about it from causing chaos in our home?

column1: N.Y.C. Indoor Dining to Reopen on Valentine’s Day
column2: On Friday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced that indoor dining in New York City could resume at up to 25 percent capacity starting on Valentine’s Day.

column2: The festivals were some of the first major events canceled back in April 2020 in the early days of the pandemic.

column2: President Biden went to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center in Bethesda, Md., on Friday to visit privately with wounded soldiers. He also toured the facility’s coronavirus vaccine distribution site.

column1: W.H.O. Delivers Update on China Visit

column1: A New Coronavirus Variant Is Spreading in New York, Researchers Report
column2: The variant contains a mutation thought to help the virus dodge the immune system, scientists said.

column1: Where a Vaccination Campaign Faces Skepticism, War and Corruption
column2: A half-million doses arrived this month in Afghanistan, where many insist the virus isn’t real and vaccines aren’t needed. Those who want the vaccine fear that only the well-connected will receive it.
column3: By David Zucchino and Najim Rahim

column1: U.S. health officials caution governors against easing restrictions, warning that a recent plunge in virus cases ‘may be stalling.’
column2: “Things are tenuous,” says Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the C.D.C. director. “Now is not the time to relax restrictions.”

column1: The Loneliest Room, for My Sister in a Nursing Home
column2: The pandemic has stolen away the chance to surround the sister we are losing to dementia with our love, so that she does not have to face death alone.

column1: The Covid Emergency Must End
column2: We might be able to achieve normalcy by summer. Our leaders should embrace the possibility.

column1: Israel’s Vaccination Results Point a Way Out of Virus Pandemic
column2: Covid cases fell dramatically and quickly among people who were vaccinated, Israeli studies found. It’s the strongest evidence yet that a robust vaccination program can tame the pandemic.
column3: By Isabel Kershner and Carl Zimmer

column1: This 105-Year-Old Beat Covid. She Credits Gin-Soaked Raisins.
column2: Lucia DeClerck, the oldest resident of her New Jersey nursing home, tested positive for the virus on her 105th birthday, one day after her second vaccine shot.

column1: Developing Potent Antivirals Is the ‘Direction of the Future’, Fauci Says
column2: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Monday the next phase in the fight against Covid-19 is developing “potent antivirals” that directly act on the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

column1: France Hired McKinsey to Help in the Pandemic. Then Came the Questions.
column2: After previously undisclosed contracts were revealed, the company has become a magnet for criticism in France’s vaccine rollout.

column1: Australia Begins Covid-19 Vaccination Campaign
column2: Australia began vaccinating its population against Covid-19 on Sunday. Jane Malysiak, 84, a resident of a nursing home in Sydney, and Prime Minister Scott Morrison were among the first to receive a vaccine.

column1: A study shows the variant spreading rapidly in Britain might make vaccines less effective.
column2: The highly infectious variant has developed a worrisome mutation, new research has found.

column1: Children and Covid
column2: As the United States continues its campaign to immunize every eligible American adult, we explore an overlooked question: When will children get the vaccine?

column1: E.U. Makes a Sudden and Embarrassing U-Turn on Vaccines
column2: Already criticized for a slow rollout for its 27 members, Brussels retreated on export controls linked to Ireland and Brexit.
column3: By Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

column1: A SoulCycle Instructor Got the Vaccine as an ‘Educator’
column2: The spin class teacher, Stacey Griffith, has since apologized. But to many, it was another example of wealthy or well-connected people cutting lines for doses.

column1: Delays Turn Canada’s Vaccination Optimism Into Anxiety
column2: After quickly approving a vaccine and getting an early start to inoculations, Canadians worry as the country falls behind in vaccinations.

column1: Pentagon Asked to Aid Vaccine Rollout
column2: The Defense Department said it would fulfill a Federal Emergency Management Agency request for help running coronavirus vaccination sites as much as it can.

column1: Black and Latino New Yorkers Trail White Residents in Vaccine Rollout
column2: Data showed that while 24% of city residents are Black, only 11% of vaccine recipients were. White New Yorkers received a disproportionate share of the shots.

column1: The State of the Virus: East Coast Lags as U.S. Sees Sustained Progress
column2: A look at this week’s news from the team tracking the coronavirus.

column1: Pay People to Get Vaccinated
column2: Once a reliable vaccine exists, it won’t stop the pandemic unless most people are willing to take it. Economics provides a solution.

column1: As Europe’s Coronavirus Cases Rise, So Do Voices Crying Hoax
column2: As health officials warn of a second major wave, growing numbers of people are dismissing the threat as media hype and sometimes embracing conspiracy theories.

column1: Gerald Ford Rushed Out a Vaccine. It Was a Fiasco.
column2: Trump should keep that in mind as he pushes for a coronavirus shot.

column1: AstraZeneca Pauses Vaccine Trial for Safety Review

column3: By Katherine J. Wu and Katie Thomas

column1: Missed Vaccines, Skipped Colonoscopies: Preventive Care Plummets
column2: Nonurgent medical procedures have seemed worth postponing in a pandemic. This could pose long-term risks, health officials fear.

column1: 9 Drug Companies Pledge to ‘Stand With Science’ on Coronavirus Vaccines
column2: The joint statement by competitors was seen as an effort to restore public trust as President Trump has pushed for a vaccine before the presidential election.

column1: What Have We Learned About Coronavirus Immunity?
column2: Antibodies are only part of the picture.

column1: What if the First Coronavirus Vaccines Aren’t the Best?

column1: What We Know About the C.D.C.’s Covid-19 Vaccine Plans
column2: The agency told public health agencies that two unidentified vaccines might be ready by October or November. We explain how vaccine trials work, when one might be ready, and who may get them first.

column1: C.D.C. Director Projects 700 Million Covid-19 Doses by April
column2: In his Senate testimony, Dr. Robert R. Redfield said that some Americans will not be able to access a coronavirus vaccine until July 2021.
